pullRequest.body:
`bound` proves inequalities that follow "obviously by structure", assuming nonnegativity or positivity of subterms where necessary.  It is built on top of Aesop.  It has significant overlap with `positivity` and `gcongr`, but can also switch back and forth between those modes (such as when proving `0 < a * b - a * c` from `0 < a`, `c < b`).

Zulip discussion: https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/239415-metaprogramming-.2F-tactics/topic/.60bound.60.20mixes.20.60gcongr.60.20and.20.60positivity.60/near/412120380

---

Here's an initial implementation of the `bound` tactic discussed on Zulip, upstreamed from https://github.com/girving/ray/blob/main/Ray/Tactic/Bound.lean.  Happy to do whatever cleanup or further testing is deemed useful.  Some notes:

1. `mul_inv_le_one_of_nonneg_of_le` and `Real.pi_nonneg` should probably be moved to their appropriate places, but I wanted to check first.
2. `le_self_pow_of_pos` is a wart due to `bound` not knowing what to do with `n ≠ 0` goals.  One option would be give `bound` a rule for `Nat.pos_iff_ne_zero`, so that `n ≠ 0` automatically turns into `0 < n`.
3. `Bound.lean` currently imports `Mathlib.Analysis.Analytic.Basic` just to add `r_pos` as a forward rule.  If this rule is reasonable it would of course be better to move that to `Mathlib.Analysis.Analytic.Basic` to remove the heavy import.
4. I added two more triangle inequalities in a separate PR (which also shows up as a commit within this one until that other PR is dealt with):

- [x] depends on: https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/10561 [extra triangle inequalities]

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#10561~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (🤖). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

I made two tiny PRs for the two general purpose lemmas, so those can be handled independently.  I'll delete them from this one when done, but I don't think it blocks reviewing.

1. https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/10596
2. https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/10597

Thank for all the comments!  Will reply to them soon, but wanted to leave a separate thought here before I forget it.

Currently one has to manually map each lemma to the appropriate rule type and priority, but I think this could be mostly automated:

1. Have a single `bound` attribute that all the lemmas are registered to.
2. For each, count the number of (1) general inequality hypotheses and (2) positivity/nonnegativity hypotheses, then map to priority based on lexicographic ordering of (1) and (2). 

Does that seem reasonable?  I can make that refactoring if so, and it would make it way easier to register new bound lemmas.
If this is your manual algorithm wrt applying the priorities to these lemmas, I think this would be most welcome!

Priority selection is automatic now (see `Bound/Attribute.lean` for the algorithm), which makes registering lemmas way cleaner.  The algorithm works well (I visually inspected everything it output, then confirmed that all of https://github.com/girving/ray works with the new algorithm), but it is arguably missing some `whnf` calls (basically, it assumes everything is already in sufficiently normal form).  Advice on whether I should clean it further is appreciated.

This will make it way easier to register lemmas downstream as well, as one doesn't have to think about priorities.

> It has significant overlap with `positivity`

Can it in fact not call `positivity`?

It can call positivity as a closing tactic, and happy to add that if it seems reasonable, but this can do positivity goals that positivity cannot (in particular `0 < b - a`).  So I wouldn’t want to descend to that for all nonnegativity and positivity goals.

I argued before that `positivity` should know that `a < b → 0 < b - a`, so it really feels like you could plug `bound` on `positivity` by adding a parameter to `positivity` calls to use `gcongr`-like behavior.

Basically I'm trying to decide whether "Run `positivity` and `gcongr` intertwiningly" is a reasonable algorithm for `bound`. Because if it is that means we don't need to maintain an extra attribute for `bound`.

`bound` is slightly more general than positivity and gcongr interleaved, since it also knows how to go from `0 <= a <= b` to `a / b <= 1` for each.

But if we could extend to handle that kind of thing too, I’d be open to that alternative.  My sense from the thread linked in the original post is that there isn’t interest in broadening positivity and gcongr, though.
I just think it would be a shame to have three tools designed to solve basically the same problems.
What’s the standard method of establishing consensus, given that this doesn’t seem to be general current view?  (E.g., extending positivity further.)
Talk to Zulip, open an outstandingly good PR, run performance tests...

Done.
Merge conflict resolved. @YaelDillies: What's the next step?
Okay, actually fixed now. Some Mathlib refactors meant that `Bound.lean` no longer imported `pow` inequalities, so I moved those annotations out of `Bound.lean`.
All looks good to me. Maybe Damiano and Kim can give the PR one last round of comments?

:v: girving can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

How do I kick the CI so that it runs again? This seems transient:

```
Warning: some files were not found in the cache.
This usually means that your local checkout of mathlib4 has diverged from upstream.
If you push your commits to a branch of the mathlib4 repository, CI will build the oleans and they will be available later.

2 download(s) failed
Error: Process completed with exit code 1.
```
@j-loreaux What's the next step? Should I still wait for the remaining two reviewers?

Now that you've been delegated, you should feel free to merge!  In any case, I'm happy with the current status!

🎉

I think things are okay. Kyle didn't revoke my delegation, so you could merge. But since I'm here:

bors merge
bors r-
Canceled.
Oops, I thought CI was successful?
Sorry, I'd missed that the attribute test was broken by the namespace change. Fixed.
@j-loreaux You up for one more merge try? I think I can't do it, since the delegation went away with the new commit.

You should still have it delegated to you; adding commits doesn't remove that as far as I know. Maybe a `bors r-` might? But I don't think so. I'm happy to merge though.

bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Neat. A few comments below
A review of the module docstring.

Thanks! There's just a small amount I want done in the test file!

bors d+
Neat. A few comments below
A review of the module docstring.

The result from my private discussion with Geoffrey is that we don't agree on whether the aesop-based approach (this PR) is better than an extension-based approach (not written anywhere, but basically some kind of chimera between `positivity` and `gcongr`, hopefully reusing most of their code and extensions). Hence I am of the opinion that we should just try out what we have, keeping in mind that we might eventually swap out implementations.

Thanks! There's just a small amount I want done in the test file!

bors d+

```suggestion
uses specialized lemmas for goals of the form `1 ≤ x, 1 < x, x ≤ 1, x < 1`.
```

```suggestion
See `test/Bound.lean` for tests.
```
I don't think this is right
Indeed, I'll accept Johan's fix.
This doesn't look like the right arrow
Sorry, it was the arrow for the iteration, since I was thinking about dynamics.  But in context \mapsto is way better.  Will fix.
Please don't switch between `Complex.abs` and `abs` here, and add a space after `←`
Fixed to `abs` everywhere, and I added the spaces.  Thanks!

```suggestion
1. `norm apply`: Lemmas which close inequalities immediately, such as `le_refl`, `Real.exp_pos`,
```
I don't follow this (probably because of my lack of experience with `aesop`). What is the connection between `safe 1` and `assumption`?

Hmm, this seems like it was me hallucinating, since actually the priority of `Assumption` is -50: https://github.com/leanprover-community/aesop/blob/master/Aesop/BuiltinRules/Assumption.lean#L14.  I'll remove the comment for now, and test whether I can shift things down once I automate priority assignment.
I tried stripping the offset when I did the automation, and it didn't make a difference.  Not sure why I thought it did before.

```suggestion
  rcases h with ⟨a1, nm⟩ | ⟨a0, a1, mn⟩
```
(more below)

Did you mean
```suggestion
/-- `bound`, but return a proof script -/
```
Broken parethentical dropped.
Same comments as in the documentation
Sorry about the `{Complex.,}abs` thing.  Unfortunately some of them work without it and some of them don't, due to imperfect inference, but I agree uniformity is good.

```suggestion
There are several cases where there are two standard ways to recurse down an inequality, and it is not
```

```suggestion
In these cases we declare a new loop with a `∨` hypothesis that covers the two cases, and register
```
This incorrectly handles meta-data: If I pass in `Zero.zero` wrapped in `mdata`, this will incorrectly say it is not zero. You should use Qq matching instead.
Thanks, will fix these soon.

Hmm, how do I use Qq matching to match a zero?  I'm not sure what the type of the `IsZero` function would be then: it seems like it has to take a `Q(...)` argument, but then the `...` has to be polymorphic and I'm not sure how to write it.
Can you look at what `positivity` does? There should be the same problem there.
Done.
Similarly here your match will fail if there's meta-data around.
Done (resp. other places, and other aesop changes).

These imports are very heavy. Is it possibly to make the file where the tactic itself is defined quite lightweight and put the `bound` support for those operations in the files where the operations are defined?
Yep, will do soon.

Done, `Bound.lean` now imports

```lean
import Aesop
import Mathlib.Algebra.Order.AbsoluteValue
import Mathlib.Algebra.Order.BigOperators.Group.Finset
import Mathlib.Algebra.Order.Field.Basic
import Mathlib.Algebra.Order.Floor
import Mathlib.Algebra.Order.Ring.Basic
import Mathlib.Algebra.Order.Ring.Defs
import Mathlib.Tactic.Bound.Attribute
import Mathlib.Tactic.Lemma
import Mathlib.Tactic.Linarith.Frontend
import Mathlib.Tactic.NormNum.Core
```

 Let me know if I should remove more of them.

Sorry, missed fixing the test, which promptly broke due to lack of imports. :)

All green now.

```suggestion
@[bound] alias \<_, Bound.coe_lt_coe_of_lt\> := coe_lt_coe
```
and elsewhere
Done, thank you!
Deserves more explanation
Added more; is that enough?
Looks good, and makes it clear that it too is not `bound`-specific
This is not `bound`-specific, right?
Yes, but I don't know where to put or name it (insufficiently familiar with tactic utilities).
I will ask for an opinion from meta reviewers
This and the next are small/specific enough that it is fine to leave them here.

```suggestion
by turning the goal into `b * c ≤ a * c`, then using `mul_le_mul_of_nonneg_right`.  `bound` also
```

```suggestion
3. Disjunctions `a ∨ b` get score 100, plus the score of `a` and `b`.
```

```suggestion
either `a ≤ c` or `b ≤ c` suffices, and we don't know which.
```

```suggestion
    a ≤ a ^ m :=
```

```suggestion
/-- Branch on `1 ≤ a ∨ a ≤ 1` for `a ^ n` -/
```

```suggestion
syntax "bound " (" [" term,* "]")? : tactic

elab_rules : tactic
  | `(tactic| bound $[[$lemmas:term,*]]?) => do
    let lemmas := (lemmas.getD ⟨#[]⟩).getElems
    Bound.addHyps lemmas
    let tac ← `(tactic| aesop (rule_sets := [Bound, -default]) (config := Bound.boundConfig))
    liftMetaTactic fun g ↦ do return (← Lean.Elab.runTactic g tac.raw).1
```
This should allow you to avoid `maybeTerms`: it leverages `.getElems`, which "does the right thing".

```suggestion
    -- Conjunctions add scores
```

```suggestion
    | _ => throwError (f!"`{decl}` has invalid type `{type}` as a 'bound' lemma: \
                          it should be an inequality")
```

```suggestion
    trace[bound.attribute] "'{decl}' has score '{score}'"
```

Thanks for writing this!

I have virtually no experience with either `Qq` or `Aesop`, so my review is very superficial.  However, it looks very good and would be happy to see how it performs in Mathlib!
What happened here? This seems like unnecessary entanglement between `bound` and `positivity`.

Previously `nnreal_coe_pos` was a private lemma in this scope. I also needed it for `bound`, so I pulled it out to a toplevel thing and called it `NNReal.coe_pos_of_pos`. Then I was told to rename it to `Bound.coe_pos_of_pos` by @YaelDillies. I did this even though it has this one other use, in part because the use is private and within the same file.

Happy to either re-add the `nnreal_coe_pos` alias (then we would have two names for the same lemma, for two different tactics), or undo the `Bound.` scoping, or do nothing.
Another options would be to use `coe_pos.mpr $pa` here, at the expense of producing a very-slightly-larger proof term.

Ah I see what happened here. My opinion is that if two tactics want to use the same non-existing lemma, then both of them should define that lemma (possibly using `alias` from an existing lemma). The point is to make sure that tactics get precisely the lemma they want, avoiding people who modify non-tactic lemmas having to figure out how to fix the tactics.

So here you should just not touch the `positivity`-specific lemma and make your own `Bound`-specific one (which can henceforth be private, 🎉)
Fixed, and I made the other `Bound` aliases private as well.
What does "has some report" mean?
Fixed: `support`.
I wonder if detecting with the goal is in `Nat` or `Int` and trying `omega` would be helpful. (No need to try this now!)
Yes, that's a good idea! I will add a TODO comment.

```suggestion
on the number and types of the lemma's hypotheses.
```
Have you tried this using `match_expr` rather than `Qq`? I'd prefer, if it makes no difference, to rely on simpler / better maintained technology.
Someone told me to use `Qq` while I was developing this, but I'm fine switching if that's desirable. I haven't heard of `match_expr`, though: where's it documented?

Hmm, I looked into `match_expr` a bit, and if possible I'd like to stick with `Qq` for at least this first PR. `match_expr` doesn't seem to have support for literal zeros, is used nowhere else in `mathlib4`, and has no documentation. The first match I tried to convert was `~q(@OfNat.ofNat.{u} _ 0 $i)`, but using an explicit `0` was a syntax error for `match_expr`, and I can't find any literal matching in the `lean4` repo. I'd be happy to do a later rewrite from `Qq` to `match_expr` if it gets more support, but it seems thin at the moment.

I'm always worried about importing significant theory in tactics files. It really ties our hands simplifying the import tree.

Could you either try to minimize these imports, or add some comments explaining why these are the minimum necessary?
Yep, I will minimize this further.

Done, the imports are now:

```
-- Bound/Init.lean
import Aesop.Frontend.Command

-- Bound/Attribute.lean
import Mathlib.Init.ZeroOne
import Mathlib.Tactic.Bound.Init
import Qq

-- Bound.lean
import Aesop
import Mathlib.Tactic.Bound.Attribute
import Mathlib.Tactic.Lemma
import Mathlib.Tactic.Linarith.Frontend
import Mathlib.Tactic.NormNum.Core
```
If I get a pointer to how to use `match_expr` I can replace the `Qq` import with that.
Can all go on one line?
Done.

```suggestion
-- This breaks without appropriate `g.withContext` use in <function-name>
```

The broken code was before the `aesop` port. Okay if I leave it in there with this comment?

```
/-- This broke without appropriate `g.withContext` use in an older implementation of `bound`.
Leaving the test here just in case. -/
```

```suggestion
```
Is this still needed?
Whoops, forgot to strip that.
I would guess you only need the first one of these, the second should never appear.
Do you mean that the first one should never appear (the `OfNat.ofNat`)? I think the one that appears is the second one (`Zero.zero`).
@eric-wieser was correct, fixed.

```suggestion
  | ~q(@OfNat.ofNat.{u} _ (nat_lit 0) $i) => return true
```
I removed this line instead, let me know if that's wrong.
Fixed the way you suggested, and added tests to verify. Thank you!
Can you add a docstring to this, explaining when it should be used? I think this docstring would be what appears when you hover over `@[bound]`.
Probably it should crossref `bound_forward`
Done, good point.
Are there cases where `gcongr` is appropriate but `bound` is not? Either way, can you answer this in the docstring of `@[bound]`?
Done.
So to be clear: *every* lemma tagged `gcongr` should also be tagged `bound`?

Sorry, should only be inequalities with `≤`; I believe `gcongr` is more general. I will make this very explicit.

I could try to make `bound` automatically look into `gcongr` inequalities using `≤` if we want, but I'd prefer to delay that to a later PR.

I just wanted to record it here for later. I'm not sure that a constant additive penalty is the appropriate solution here. It seems like you would want some sort of multiplicative penalty for anything that requires branching. I don't think this is enough of a problem to hold up the PR, but in case we have performance issues as a result of branching, I think this is a good place to look for the culprit in the future.

That makes sense, but as a subtlety one might want to attach the multiplicative penalty to the Aesop rule that does the branching on the or generated by this rule, not this rule itself. Not sure how to represent that.

You've already mentioned that `bound` has scope-overlap with `positivity` and `gcongr`. It would be nice if, in the test file, you separate out tests which should only succeed with `bound`, but neither of the others. You can leave in some which overlap, I suppose, but it would be nice to have some clear demarcation.
Will do.
Done.
I think we should put all the tactic code in `Mathlib.Tactic.Bound`
I don’t follow this comment. The only code in Attribute.lean is that used for the attributes, which are included early in Mathlib in files which should not include Bound.lean.
I'm saying to change this to `namespace Mathlib.Tactic.Bound` and change the other `namespace` in the other file too.
Is that the standard? It looks like some tactics don't do it (Linarith) and others do. I'll change it now for mine at least.

I think we should aim to have all meta code at least in the `Mathlib.Tactic` namespace. I try to put my own tactics in `Mathlib.Tactic.MyTacticName`, but it looks like I've lapsed here and there...

Precise namespacing doesn't hurt, that's for sure!
Done!
Use `Lean.MVarId.note`
Obsolete, since with your other suggestion this function vanished.

If this is really just `have`, then rather than redoing `have` I would make a `macro_rules` that expands this as `have := t1; have := t2; ...; have := tn; bound`.

There's a bug in `addHyps` where if there are any metavariables they get lost, rather than being added as new goals. Using `have` itself would avoid this.
That does seem good. Could I hint for what that syntax would look like? I haven’t dealt with macros before.

I think this should work:
```
macro_rules
  | `(tactic| bound%$tk [$[$ts],*]) => do
    let haves ← ts.mapM fun (t : Term) => withRef t `(tactic| have := $t)
    `(tactic| ($haves;* ; bound%$tk))
```
(Untested)
Works!

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Tactic.Bound): Add a `bound` tactic for inequalities by structure

* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#10561~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (🤖). Happy coding!

I made two tiny PRs for the two general purpose lemmas, so those can be handled independently.  I'll delete them from this one when done, but I don't think it blocks reviewing.

1. https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/10596
2. https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/10597
Neat. A few comments below
A review of the module docstring.

Thank for all the comments!  Will reply to them soon, but wanted to leave a separate thought here before I forget it.

Currently one has to manually map each lemma to the appropriate rule type and priority, but I think this could be mostly automated:

1. Have a single `bound` attribute that all the lemmas are registered to.
2. For each, count the number of (1) general inequality hypotheses and (2) positivity/nonnegativity hypotheses, then map to priority based on lexicographic ordering of (1) and (2). 

Does that seem reasonable?  I can make that refactoring if so, and it would make it way easier to register new bound lemmas.
If this is your manual algorithm wrt applying the priorities to these lemmas, I think this would be most welcome!

Priority selection is automatic now (see `Bound/Attribute.lean` for the algorithm), which makes registering lemmas way cleaner.  The algorithm works well (I visually inspected everything it output, then confirmed that all of https://github.com/girving/ray works with the new algorithm), but it is arguably missing some `whnf` calls (basically, it assumes everything is already in sufficiently normal form).  Advice on whether I should clean it further is appreciated.

This will make it way easier to register lemmas downstream as well, as one doesn't have to think about priorities.

> It has significant overlap with `positivity`

Can it in fact not call `positivity`?

It can call positivity as a closing tactic, and happy to add that if it seems reasonable, but this can do positivity goals that positivity cannot (in particular `0 < b - a`).  So I wouldn’t want to descend to that for all nonnegativity and positivity goals.

I argued before that `positivity` should know that `a < b → 0 < b - a`, so it really feels like you could plug `bound` on `positivity` by adding a parameter to `positivity` calls to use `gcongr`-like behavior.

Basically I'm trying to decide whether "Run `positivity` and `gcongr` intertwiningly" is a reasonable algorithm for `bound`. Because if it is that means we don't need to maintain an extra attribute for `bound`.

`bound` is slightly more general than positivity and gcongr interleaved, since it also knows how to go from `0 <= a <= b` to `a / b <= 1` for each.

But if we could extend to handle that kind of thing too, I’d be open to that alternative.  My sense from the thread linked in the original post is that there isn’t interest in broadening positivity and gcongr, though.
I just think it would be a shame to have three tools designed to solve basically the same problems.
What’s the standard method of establishing consensus, given that this doesn’t seem to be general current view?  (E.g., extending positivity further.)
Talk to Zulip, open an outstandingly good PR, run performance tests...

The result from my private discussion with Geoffrey is that we don't agree on whether the aesop-based approach (this PR) is better than an extension-based approach (not written anywhere, but basically some kind of chimera between `positivity` and `gcongr`, hopefully reusing most of their code and extensions). Hence I am of the opinion that we should just try out what we have, keeping in mind that we might eventually swap out implementations.
